titleStmt.title: A Case-Control Study to Identify Community Venues Associated with Genetically-clustered, Multidrug-resistant Tuberculosis Disease in Lima, Peru

analytic.title: A Case-Control Study to Identify Community Venues Associated with Genetically-clustered, Multidrug-resistant Tuberculosis Disease in Lima, Peru

biblStruct.note: Received 23 March 2018; editorial decision 26 July 2018; accepted 24 August 2018;

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Background.
The majority of tuberculosis transmission occurs in community settings.
Our primary aim in this study was to assess the association between exposure to community venues and multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis.
Our secondary aim was to describe the social networks of MDR tuberculosis cases and controls.
Methods.
We recruited laboratory-confirmed MDR tuberculosis cases and community controls that were matched on age and sex.
Whole-genome sequencing was used to identify genetically clustered cases.
Venue tracing interviews (nonblinded) were conducted to enumerate community venues frequented by participants.
Logistic regression was used to assess the association between MDR tuberculosis and person-time spent in community venues.
A location-based social network was constructed, with respondents connected if they reported frequenting the same venue, and an exponential random graph model (ERGM) was fitted to model the network.
Results.
We enrolled 59 cases and 65 controls.
Participants reported 729 unique venues.
The mean number of venues reported was similar in both groups (P = .92).
Person-time in healthcare venues (adjusted odds ratio [aOR] = 1.67,
schools (aOR = 1.53,
and transportation venues (aOR = 1.25, P = .03)
was associated with MDR tuberculosis.
Healthcare venues, markets, cinemas, and transportation venues were commonly shared among clustered cases.
The ERGM indicated significant community segregation between cases and controls.
Case networks were more densely connected.
Conclusions.
Exposure to healthcare venues, schools, and transportation venues was associated with MDR tuberculosis.
Intervention across the segregated network of case venues may be necessary to effectively stem transmission.
Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) requires longer treatment regimens, is associated with worse outcomes, and threatens to derail global tuberculosis (TB) control efforts [1,2].
Recent studies have found high levels of TB transmission between unrelated households in Peru and other high-burden settings [3][4][5][6].
These findings suggest MDR-TB transmission may occur during exposure to infectious cases in community settings [6,7].

The identification of community settings associated with MDR-TB may inform public health surveillance, enhance case finding, and identify settings where environmental intervention, such as UV irradiation or improved air ventilation, may reduce exposure and transmission risk [8].

Prior investigations have used venue-tracing interviews, diaries, and surveys of diagnosed TB patients to determine settings of possible transmission; however, these studies were predominantly descriptive and did not estimate the measures of association between TB and exposure to community settings [9][10][11][12][13].
These prior studies also focused mainly on drug-sensitive TB and not MDR-TB, and rarely leveraged social network analyses to evaluate data derived from venue-tracing interviews [9,10].

Gardy et al. used both whole-genome sequencing and social network questionnaires to investigate a TB outbreak in British Columbia; however, their social network investigation was limited to 8 respondents and the questionnaires were limited to known contacts [11].

Data from venue-tracing interviews can be used to construct social networks between respondents and unknown contacts in shared community venues, offering a more comprehensive view of a community's social network [14].

Social networks and contact patterns may influence the spread and epidemiology of infectious diseases [15][16][17][18][19], and may be studied to reveal important social network properties influencing the spread of MDR-TB in community settings.
The primary objective of this study was to investigate the association between exposure to community settings and the odds of contracting MDR-TB.
We hypothesized that MDR-TB cases would report more person-time exposure to community venues than controls.
The secondary objective was to visualize and statistically model and characterize the social networks of MDR-TB cases, to identify the social contact processes associated with MDR-TB.
A case-control study design was used to test the primary hypothesis.
Cases were patients with confirmed MDR-TB residing in Callao and Lima Sur (Supplementary Figure S1).
These 2 regions cover extensive areas of Lima and consistently report a high proportion of incident MDR-TB cases [20].
Cases were recruited from a completed parent study, which enrolled a cohort of MDR-TB patients between 2010-2013 in Callao and Lima Sur [21].
The parent study was designed to study the transmission of MDR-TB relative to drug-sensitive TB.
All MDR-TB cases were whole-genome sequenced to identify genetically clustered cases [21].

Cases were considered clustered if their MDR-TB strain matched the strain of at least 1 other case within 5 or fewer single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) [22].The majority of cases were genetically clustered (68%), and therefore likely to have arisen from a recent transmission [23].
Community members with no history of TB that lived near MDR-TB cases were selected as controls.
We recruited community health workers that worked in the health clinics in which cases were diagnosed.

Additional community controls were recruited by referral from community health workers and sourced from churches, schools, restaurants, and communal kitchens, where the community health workers also worked.
Controls were frequency matched to cases based on study region, age (± 5 years), and sex.
The study protocol, consent forms, and data collection instruments were reviewed and approved by the Institutional Committee of Ethics for Humans at La Universidad Peruana Cayetano Heredia.
We collected data through face-to-face, nonblinded interviews and used a venue-tracing interview guide to enumerate the venues frequented by cases and controls.

Cases were asked to name venues visited during the month prior to MDR-TB diagnosis, defined as the date of sputum isolate collection prior to treatment, and healthy controls were asked about venues visited during the month prior to study enrollment.
When cases were unavailable, deceased, or too ill to respond, proxy interviews were conducted with available family members (eg, spouses, parents).
We asked participants to report the names, addresses, and types of venues visited; the average frequency of visits (daily, weekly, biweekly, etc.); and the average duration of visits in hours.
Person-time per venue was estimated by multiplying the weekly frequency of visits by the mean duration for each visit.
For example, for someone frequenting a market 3 times a week for 1 hour per visit, the weekly person-time would be 3 hours.
Logistic regression was used to estimate the association between time spent in community venues and MDR-TB, and to report adjusted odds ratios (OR) as the measure of association.
Education and income level were included in the final models, as a bivariate analysis showed they were associated with cases and person-time in community venues.
The frequency-matched variables (age, sex, and region) were included in the final models.
Likelihood ratio tests were used to assess interaction by study region and person-time, and results were stratified by study region when a significant region by person-time interaction (P < .10)
was observed.
Descriptive statistics and regression models were done in Stata 14 [24].
We used data from the venue-tracing interviews to construct 2-mode social networks, showing respondents connected to venues they reported frequenting.
The 2-mode networks were visualized and reviewed to identify the venues most visited by cases and controls, respectively.
We reviewed the 2-mode networks of each genetic cluster with >1 case to identify shared venues that could be considered epidemiologic links or sites of transmission.
Next, the 2-mode networks were converted to 1-mode "location-based social networks" (LSN), showing respondents connected to other respondents when they reported frequenting the same venue.

We calculated the network density (ie, proportion of actual connections out of all potential connections) of the 1-mode networks of cases and controls to compare the difference in inter-connectedness among the 2 groups for each venue type [13].
In these LSNs, greater network density indicates greater inter-connectedness among respondents through shared venues.

We used exponential random graph models (ERGMs) to model the 1-mode LSNs to evaluate the extent to which cases were connected to other cases (ie, homophily); in other words, the extent to which cases tended to frequent the same venues as other cases.
ERGMs are a class of models for analyzing and modeling observed social networks [25].
ERGMs were fitted to the 1-mode LSN assembled from the venue-tracing interviews with model terms for homophily by case status, age, sex, education, income, and region.
A term for geometrically-weighted edgewise shared partners was included to capture social network transitivity and improve model fit [26].
We used the igraph and statnet R packages for all network analyses [27][28][29].
A total of 59 cases (30 in Callao and 29 in Lima Sur) and 65 controls (33 in Callao and 32 in Lima Sur) were enrolled.
There were 40 (68%) genetically-clustered cases, which were genetically matched with at least 1 other case.
There were 15 (27%) cases reported with at least 1 prior episode of drug-sensitive TB, of which 8 (53%) were genetically clustered; there was also 1 case which had 1 prior episode of MDR-TB.
Frequency matching between cases and controls was achieved by region, age, and sex (Table 1).
We conducted 18 (31%) of the case interviews by proxy.
There were no significant demographic differences between primary cases (those directly interviewed) and proxy cases (those interviewed by proxy; Supplementary Table S1).
A total of 729 unique venues were reported; cases reported 352 unique venues, controls reported 427 unique venues (50 venues were reported by both cases and controls).

Three-fourths of the 50 venues reported by both cases and controls were healthcare venues (n = 14, 28%) and markets (n = 23, 46%); 10 (20%) of the case-control-shared venues included restaurants, cinemas, schools, and transportation venues (Supplementary Table S2).
The mean number of venues reported was similar between cases (mean = 8.3, standard deviation = 3.0) and controls (mean = 8.4, standard deviation = 5.7; P = .92).
There was no difference in the mean number of venues reported between proxy and primary cases (P = .73).

Among cases, the most frequently-reported venue types were healthcare venues, markets, and stores; cases reported the greatest amount of weekly person-hours in healthcare venues, transportation venues, schools, and markets (Figure 1).
Controls reported visiting markets, stores, and restaurants most frequently; the majority of controls' weekly person-hours were in markets, offices, and stores (Figure 1).
Cases reported significantly more time in healthcare (P < .001)
and transportation venues (P = .003;
Table 2).

The adjusted logistic regression models indicated that the odds of MDR-TB are increased by 15% for every additional 10 weekly person-hours spent in community settings (OR = 1.15, confidence interval = 1.02-1.30;
Table 2).
Time in healthcare venues, schools, and transportation venues were all significantly associated with MDR-TB (P < .05).
There was a significant interaction by region for time in stores, transportation venues, and bars/clubs (Supplementary Table S3).
A visual representation of the 2-mode networks (respondents linked to venues) and respective 1-mode LSNs are shown in Figures 2 and 3, respectively.
In Callao, 6 of the top 10 venues most visited by controls were large markets, whereas 7 of the top 10 venues visited by cases were hospitals or clinics (Supplementary Table S4).
In Lima Sur, clinics and markets were the most commonly-shared venues among cases.
There was 1 cinema in Lima Sur that was reported by 8 (14%) cases (Supplementary Table S4).
Excluding healthcare venues, the most commonly-reported venue type among cases was markets, and 4 markets were shared by 2 or more cases and controls (Supplementary Table S5).
2-mode networks, stratified by cases and region, are provided in Supplementary Figure S2.
There were 8 unique genetic clusters, ranging in size from 2 to 7 cases, and epidemiologic links (i.e., shared venues) were found in all but 1 cluster.
The clusters are described and visualized in Supplementary Table S6.
Healthcare venues were found in 7 clusters.
Markets, transportation venues, and cinemas were also links among clustered cases.
There were also 2 cases in 1 cluster that reported spending time in the same prison.
In 1 of 2 clusters with cross-region cases, large markets and hospitals were the primary epidemiologic links (Supplementary Table S6).
Among cases, network density was the greatest through shared healthcare venues, markets, and cinemas (Table 3).
Among controls, network density was greatest through shared markets, followed by stores, then healthcare venues.
No cases were connected through shared stores and no controls were connected through shared bars/clubs.
The network density based on cinemas was the highest among clustered cases (Table 3).
The network densities, stratified by region, are reported in Supplementary Table S7.
The final ERGM for the LSN of both regions showed significant community segregation, as indicated by a statistically significant homophily effect among cases (Coef = 2.03, P < .0001)
and controls (Coef = 0.27, P = .002;
Supplementary Table S8).
Model estimates indicate the probability that 2 cases in Callao with similar education and income levels would frequent the same venue would be 27.4%.
In comparison, the probability that 2 controls in Callao with similar education and income levels would frequent the same venue would be 6.1%.
In other words, MDR-TB cases were 4.5 times more likely than controls to report frequenting the same community venue.

Our analysis demonstrated that MDR-TB patients tended to spend significantly more time than matched controls in community settings, particularly in healthcare venues, schools, and transportation venues (i.e., bus stops/lines, train stations, and airports).
Healthcare venues, markets, and cinemas were the most common epidemiologic links between cases, and may be potential sites of transmission.
Markets were frequently shared by both cases and controls and are potential sites for infectious-to-susceptible exposure.

These findings highlight opportunities for health ministries to implement environmental improvements, such as enhanced ventilation and UV irradiation, to reduce the risk of community exposure and transmission at these venues.
Reducing transmissibility within MDR-TB hotspots by targeting environmental interventions in venues where exposure risk is high may have considerable community-wide benefits [30].
Our study demonstrates the utility of combining venue-tracing questionnaires with whole-genome sequencing to identify new areas of potential transmission.
Network density based on all venues was greater in the LSN of cases compared to that of controls, indicating that cases are more inter-connected through community venues than controls.
The stratified analysis showed that healthcare venues were the primary venue connecting cases, and are undoubtedly important venues for infection control.

In addition to healthcare venues, LSNs based on markets, cinemas, bars, and transportation venues also had high case-network densities and may be candidate venues for MDR-TB infection control or case finding.
Greater network density has been correlated with increased infection risk in simulation studies, and may explain how outbreaks of TB tend to circulate within defined sub-populations [15].
A network analysis showed that case and control communities are highly segregated [31], with the strong separation of cases and controls into distinct network communities.
This finding suggests that environmental interventions should be applied across the distinct network of venues frequented by cases, rather than in 1 site alone.
Furthermore, resources should not be focused on venues frequented only by controls, where the risk of exposure to MDR-TB may be very low.
Social segregation may be a key driver of MDR-TB in this community, as reflected in the observed difference in income and education levels between cases and controls.
Segregation may have direct effects on the transmission of TB by concentrating impoverished populations into small geographic areas with poor housing and limited access to healthcare [32].

Spatial analyses of MDR-TB cases have found hotspots of localized transmission in areas of Lima, suggesting that the transmission of MDR-TB occurs in small geographic areas that may have formed by socially-segregated enclaves [33,34].
Our results are supported by previous studies that have found healthcare venues to be high-risk environments for MDR-TB transmission in Lima [33][34][35].
Venue-tracing studies in Uganda have found that nearly all identified clusters of unrelated TB patients were only epidemiologically linked through shared healthcare venues [9,13].
We are unable to confirm whether cases were exposed to MDR-TB and infected during healthcare visits or were infected elsewhere and visited clinics more frequently to address reactivated diseases.

However, the healthcare venues reported by cases were visited prior to their diagnoses, so the association between cases and healthcare utilization is unlikely to be confounded by TB treatment uptake [35].
Schools and transportation venues have been reported as sites of significant community contact, where prolonged and close exposure to infectious cases may be likely [10,36].

While our results are similar to previous studies of drug-sensitive TB cases [9,13], we cannot definitively conclude the venues identified are generalizable to drug-sensitive TB populations, given the use of a healthy, TB-free control group; however, the advantage of using TB-free controls is the identification of venues where susceptible-to-infectious cross-exposure is possible.

MDR-TB is associated with greater catastrophic costs due to treatment than drug-sensitive TB, and MDR-TB patients are more likely to have adverse outcomes, likely influencing mobility and community venue types frequented; however, none of the cases were hospitalized and all were sufficiently ambulant to visit clinics and other community venues [2].
There were several limitations to this study.

Proxy interviews were required for 18 (31%) of the cases because they were either too ill or had died by the time of our interview; however, there were no demographic differences between proxy and primary cases, indicating any potential bias may be minimal.
Field data on participation refusals were unfortunately not digitized, precluding a comparison analysis of case participants and non-participants.

The timeframes of interviews were also different for cases and controls; cases were interviewed about venues frequented during the month prior to diagnosis, while controls were interviewed about venues frequented in the month prior to their interview.
Focusing on the month prior to diagnosis may have biased the frequency of healthcare utilization upwards, as cases sought care for pre-diagnosis illnesses.
Future studies might focus on case recall periods before symptoms occurred, to ascertain venue exposure prior to any illness-mediated changes in venue utilization habits.

Nevertheless, since cases are highly infectious prior to treatment, focusing on venue visits prior to diagnosis is important for identifying places of concentrated infectious case activity where MDR-TB exposure may occur.

Fixing recall periods for controls to the month prior to our interviews may also have introduced differential recall bias by fixing temporality and seasonality as compared to cases; differentials in the frequency of national holidays or vacation seasons could have biased reported venue utilization.

Statistical adjustment was used to account for the significant difference in income and education among cases and controls; however, given the use of broad binary indicators to control for socioeconomic status, residual confounding may still be a concern.
Future studies should focus on the detailed collection of socioeconomic data or control for socioeconomic status in the study design.
Several cases had prior episodes of TB, suggesting resistance could have been acquired rather than transmitted and limiting our ability to conclude cases were infected in reported venues.

However, over half the cases with previous TB were genetically clustered, providing support for recent transmission, and past studies have documented the high frequency of community-based MDR-TB transmission in Lima [3].

The accuracy of SNP thresholds to determine genetic clustering is dependent upon a number of factors, including strain diversity, mutation rates, complete case detection, and the identification of epidemiologic links between cases [37].
Strain diversity in Lima has been well documented, suggesting small SNP differences are likely instances of transmission [3,38,39].
The use of a 5 SNP threshold in our study was informed by Walker et al., who found epidemiologic links between cases with up to 5 SNP differences, as was the case in the present study [22].
Increasing the threshold to ≤10 SNPs did not have an appreciable effect on the number of clustered cases or epidemiologic links found (Supplementary Table S9).
Finally, we did not complete an environmental assessment of each venue and are unable to comment on the transmission risk in specific venues.
In summary, MDR-TB patients spent significantly more time in distinct and segregated healthcare venues, schools, and transportation venues, which were associated with increased odds of MDR-TB.
The LSN analysis revealed that genetically-clustered MDR-TB patients were distinct and significantly segregated from matched controls.

This finding suggests the need to concentrate interventions at those venues utilized and shared by high-risk communities and not utilized by low-risk communities, in order to have the maximum impact on controlling disease spread.
Figure 2. The 2-mode location-based social network of cases and controls across both regions.
The 2-mode network represent the participants connected to venues they reported frequenting.
Cases are represented as dark gray circles and controls are represented as light gray circles.
Venues are represented as white boxes, with a numeric code corresponding to the venue type.
For clarity, only venues reported by at least 2 participants are visualized.
The venue codes are: 1 = healthcare, 3 = market, 4 = store, 5 = church, 7 = restaurant, 9 = cinema, 11 = school, and 12 = transportation.
Figure 3.
The 2-mode and 1-mode location-based social networks of cases and controls, stratified by region.
The 2-mode networks represent the participants connected to venues they reported frequenting.
Cases are represented as dark gray circles and controls are represented as light gray circles.
Venues are represented as white boxes, with a numeric code corresponding to the venue type.
In the 1-mode network, participants are connected if they report frequenting the same venue.
For clarity, only venues reported by at least 2 participants are visualized.
The venue codes are: 1 = healthcare, 3 = market, 4 = store, 5 = church, 7 = restaurant, 9 = cinema, 11 = school, and 12 = transportation.

figure.head: Table 1 . Demographic and Behavioral Characteristics of Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis (MDR-TB) Cases and Controls

p.s: Abbreviations: MDR-TB, multidrug-resistant tuberculosis; PEN, Peruvian Nuevo Sol; SD, standard deviation.a
P values based on t-tests (continuous) and chi-square tests (categorical).b
Includes students and retirees.

figure.head: Table 2 . Mean Weekly Person-Time (Hours) at Each Venue Type and Adjusted Odds Ratios (ORs) for the Association Between Person-Time (Per 10 Hours) and Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis (MDR-TB) by Venue Type

p.s: Bold P values are significant (P < .05).Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; MDR-TB, multidrug-resistant tuberculosis; OR, odds ratio; SD, standard deviation.aBased
on ordinal logistic regression, adjusted for income and education.bAdjusted
for age, sex, region, education, and income.Figure 1.
Total venues and person-hours reported by case and control, stratified by venue type.
(A) Bars indicate the total number of venues reported by cases and controls, stratified by venue type; grey bars are cases and white bars are controls.
(B) Bars indicate the total number of person-hours reported by cases and controls, stratified by venue type; grey bars are cases and white bars are controls.

figure.head: Table 3 . Network Densities of Location-based Social Networks by Venue Type and Case Type

p.s: is measured as the proportion of actual ties among nodes in a network, divided by the number of all total possible ties in a network.
Network densities of location-based social networks represent the proportion of a network connected through shared venues.
a Office, Residence, Other, and Parks/recreation were omitted because they did not connect participants (ie, network densities were 0).
Empty cells represent a network density of 0.
Density
